A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like: The problem with TLJ is not that it betrays the diehard fans' expectations and far-fetched theories. The problem is that it fails to deliver a story that works on a fundamental level. Red herrings leading to meaningless plot twists all over the place; characters that instead of developing since TFA become more wooden and predictable; lame diversions and subplots that change absolutely nothing; plot holes and implausible 'miracles' that defy the tone and rules of the Star Wars universe; anticlimactic results of almost every action taken by the protagonists; continuous attempts to ridicule even the most dramatic moments; waste of beloved and potentially compelling characters for no reason. \n\nCertain elements of the core concept (the whole 'duality' theme of Rey-Kylo\, Luke as a bitter hermit that needs to redeem himself\, etc) are not that bad\, but the way they were explored makes TLJ a beautifully crafted and excellently promoted blockbuster with a script any stoned undergrad film student could write in a weekend.
